Award.AwardTitle: Low Cost Generalized Coupled Cluster Theory for Static and Dynamic Correlations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gustavo Scuseria of Rice University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop novel, efficient and accurate methods to treat molecules and materials in which the motion of electrons is strongly correlated. Computational methods play a key role in understanding chemical and physical behavior and therefore can help guide the development of transformative technologies which rely on novel material properties. However, there are important problems for which the existing techniques are inadequate. Most prominently, current computational tools do not properly describe the strong correlations which are responsible for superconductivity and various important magnetic phenomena. This research seeks to remedy that deficiency by extending conventional methods in a new and unique direction. These new methods will be applied to study the strong correlations in graphitic systems, which serve as prototypes for systems displaying magnetic ordering. In the longer term, the tools developed in this proposal will be useful for other researchers in chemistry, physics, and materials science as well. A diverse group of graduate students and postdoctoral associates are involved in carrying out this research.


In order to accomplish these goals, Scuseria and coworkers combine the recently developed pair coupled cluster theory (which is able to describe strong static correlations) with Lie algebraic similarity transformation (which is able to describe the remaining weak correlations needed to reach quantitative accuracy). The combination of these two techniques should describe both strong and weak correlations with reasonable expense while avoiding the unphysical symmetry breaking which more conventional methods require but which makes their predictions somewhat suspect. The applications to fullerenes, graphene nanoribbons, and nanodots will demonstrate the capabilities of this new computational approach and will help explain their unique properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Computational quantum chemistry methods have become an important tool in the theoretical prediction of chemical properties and in aiding experiments in the interpretation of new chemical phenomena. Modeling molecular properties  and chemical reactions using quantum mechanical methods is of relevance to issues of national security, energy, and the environment.  However, the description of strong (also known as static or non-dynamical) correlation in an accurate yet computationally affordable way remains a significant challenge for understanding emerging phenomena in chemistry, physics, and materials science. The research carried out in this grant encompassed new models for accurately and efficiently describing strong correlation. Together with tools previously developed in the PI's research group, the proposed methods were applied to study aspects of graphene nanoribbons and carbon nanodots, important building blocks of next generation electronics.

Graduate students and postdoctoral researchers who participated in this project have developed important skills in computer implementation of major new methodologies in quantum chemistry and their application to chemical problems of practical relevance. As a specific outcome, this research project produced 15 publications in peer-reviewed journals for disseminating the research outcomes to the broad community of scientists and the public.

The methods developed during this grant have significantly enhanced the capabilities of the scientific community to model and study molecules and materials. The research has had a considerable impact on areas where quantum molecular modeling is routinely employed, particularly the electronics, energy, and defense industries, where next generation materials and devices are being developed and studied. The students and fellows working on this project have benefited from gaining skills valuable to future employers. Ultimately, society as a whole benefits from the advanced materials and technology that this research has and will continue to develop.
